Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CCSS: A Distributed Computation Framework for Networked Sensing and Control

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective:
The objective of this project is to develop a unified computation framework for distributed adaptive sensing and control in stochastic multi-agent networks with either static or dynamic states, coupled with model uncertainties. In such a fully distributed information processing and control paradigm, collaborative communication and participation at the agent level is explored to build efficient scalable architectures for real-time pervasive decision making with provable performance guarantees. The distributed methodologies are amenable to real-time implementation and adaptation over parametric switching and uncertainties, through proper exploitation of locally sensed data. The resulting mixed-time-scale information and cyber/physical dynamics are analyzed with new novel techniques in stochastic analysis, with special considerations over the associated non-Markovian properties.

Intellectual merit:
The intellectual merit is lying in the fact the proposed distributed adaptive framework involves a complex and subtle closed-loop interplay among stochastic learning, estimation, and communication, where the proposed approach leads to the novel mixed-time-scale sequential stochastic schemes of the consensus + innovation type. The dynamics of these procedures are non-Markovian, for which a completely new and transformative systematic approach is proposed to conduct the system performance analysis.

Broader impacts:
The broader impacts are multi-fold. The results will enable efficient cyber-physical system operations, and will provide new methodologies for advanced dynamic system analysis. The proposed concurrent education program addresses the undergraduate and graduate education issues in multiple aspects: teaching, training, and mentoring, with outreach to the community and under-represented minority groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research goal of this proposed program is to develop unified computation frameworks for distributed adaptive sensing and control in stochastic multi-agent networks, such as large critical cyber-physical systems (e.g., the smart grid) and dynamic communication systems (e.g., the cognitive radio network). As an alternative to the existing centralized decision making paradigm, we targeted at distributed scalable operating architectures with sound guarantees of real-time responsiveness and adaptability to system perturbations and uncertainties. With this vision, we developed solutions on the lines of distributed but collaborative learning and control, which are capable of: a) exploiting in real-time the sensing enhancement with multi-agent diversified observations; b) adapting to unknown model uncertainties of the networked system through online learning over the locally sensed data in conjunction with the decision making procedure; and c) providing pervasive network-wide intelligence to improve the performance of local controllers by appropriately distributing the information processing and communication overhead among the various network entities. In particular, we have been focusing on the following research efforts: 1) distributed estimation over big data sets via large deviation analysis; 2) distributed estimation with quantized inter-agent communication; 3) distributed quickest detection schemes. For each effort, specific algorithms were developed with performance guarantees proved by theorems. Furthermore, all the analytical results were validated with thorough numerical simulations. 

The intellectual merit is lying in the fact the proposed distributed adaptive frameworks involve complex and subtle closed-loop interplays among stochastic learning, estimation, and communication, where the proposed approaches lead to novel mixed-time-scale sequential stochastic schemes. The dynamics of these procedures are generally non-Markovian, for which new and transformative systematic approaches were proposed to conduct the system performance analysis.

The broader impacts are multi-fold. The results will enable efficient cyber-physical system operations, and will provide new methodologies for advanced dynamic system analysis. The concurrent education program addressed the undergraduate and graduate education issues in multiple aspects: teaching, training, and mentoring, with outreach to the community and under-represented minority groups.
